awd_titl_txt: ADVANCE Institutional Transformation at Clemson University
awd_abstract_narration:
The ADVANCE program is designed to foster gender equity through a focus on the identification and elimination of organizational barriers that impede the full participation and advancement of women faculty in academic institutions.  Organizational barriers that inhibit equity may exist in areas such as policy, practice, culture, and organizational climate.  The ADVANCE Institutional Transformation (ADVANCE-IT) track supports the development of innovative organizational change strategies within an institution of higher education to enhance gender equity in the science, technology, engineering, and math (STEM) disciplines.

Clemson University will implement TIGERS ADVANCE (Transforming the Institution through Gender Equity, Retention, and Support): a set of policy changes, procedural innovations, and institutional programs to improve the representation and status of women in STEM at Clemson.  TIGERS ADVANCE has five goals: (a) transform the culture and improve the campus climate, (b) increase the representation of women in STEM disciplines, (c) ensure equitable workload distribution, (d) enhance faculty mentoring and leadership development, and (e) implement family-friendly policies.  The social science research project embedded in the project will focus on chairs' decision making related to service assignments and workload among faculty.  

Clemson University's ADVANCE-IT project is grounded in organizational identity theory.  This is an innovative approach that envisions fostering individual identification with the university by creating the conditions for fair treatment of and improved institutional support for all faculty.  Clemson is the leading STEM education institution in South Carolina, and will work through a regional network of institutions of higher education to communicate findings, provide policy recommendations, and share best practices to ensure recruitment, advancement, and retention of STEM women faculty.

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of the grant period (2016-20230, a total of 1,949 individuals participated in 126 activities under the TIGERS (Transforming the Institution for Gender Equity, Retention, and Support) ADVANCE-IT award.  Programs were developed that supported women in STEM through enhanced allyship, mentoring and leadership development.  Departments and colleges across the university participated in faculty and administrator workshops to learn ways to mitigate bias in the workplace, become allies for women and historically marginalized identity faculty and conduct more equitable reviews for promotion and tenure and broaden applicant pools in faculty searches.  These programs (TIGERS Advocates, Implicit Bias in the Workplace, Faculty Time towards Equitable Workloads) raised awareness of inequities that existed across campus and provided departments and colleges with real tools to improve policies and practices to increase the sense of belonging (One Clemson) in our organizational strategic plan.  Family and work/life balance policies (Dual Career Hiring, Family Support and Accommodation Plans) were implemented as a result of TIGERS ADVANCE and have supported hundreds of faculty in relocating to faculty and staff jobs at Clemson and the surrounding community and earning paid leave for birth or adoption of a child or other family care needs.  The broader impacts of the grant have resulted in increased leadership positions for women faculty at Clemson (Provost?s Office, College Deans, Associate Deans, Department and School Chairs and Associate Chairs) as a result of programs developed by TIGERS ADVANCE that provided mentorship and leadership development to faculty, particularly those from underrepresented and historically marginalized identities (Trailblazers and University Mentoring Committee). Visiting scholars hosted by the Distinguished Speaker Series and development of Clemson Universities annual ?Picture a Scholar At Clemson? Women?s Symposium have showcased the many talents and contributions that women throughout the country have contributed to the sciences, arts and humanities and the many women scholars that contribute to research and educational excellence here at Clemson.

TIGERS ADVANCE has now transitioned into a permanent office, Faculty ADVANCEment Office, now housed within the Vice President for Academic Affairs and Provost?s Office and reports to the Senior Associate Provost for Faculty Affairs.  Major goals of the Faculty ADVANCEment Office are to develop and support university-wide mentoring programs for mid-career faculty and develop research-informed tools and guidance towards equitable reappointment, tenure and promotion review of faculty.  The office is staffed by a 75% administrative faculty director, two Provost?s faculty fellows (25-50% effort) and a full time staff program coordinator.  Plans to hire a 3-year rotating postdoctoral or research scholar beginning in 2024 are in place to support the research efforts of this office.
